title: A Phase 2/3 Multicenter, Placebo-controlled, Randomized, Double-blind, Parallel-group Comparison Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Brexpiprazole (OPC-34712) in the Treatment of Patients With Agitation Associated With Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type
description_brief: To evaluate the superiority of brexpiprazole 1 mg or 2 mg over placebo after a 10-week treatment regimen for agitation associated with dementia of the Alzheimer's type in patients who require medication, and to investigate the safety of brexpiprazole and identify the optimum dose.

groups.title: Brexpiprazole 1 mg
groups.description: Participants received a brexpiprazole 0.5 mg tablet once daily for 1 week followed by a 1 mg tablet once daily for 9 weeks.

groups.title: Brexpiprazole 2 mg
groups.description: Participants received a brexpiprazole 0.5 mg tablet once daily for the first week, followed by a 1 mg tablet once daily for the second week, and then, subsequently, a 2 mg tablet once daily for the following 8 weeks.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Participants received placebo tablet once daily for 10 weeks.

groups.title: Brexpiprazole 1 mg
groups.description: Participants received a brexpiprazole 0.5 mg tablet once daily for 1 week followed by a 1 mg tablet once daily for 9 weeks.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Cohen-Manfield Agitation Inventory(CMAI) Score at 10 Weeks After Dosing.
outcomeMeasures.description: The CMAI assessed the frequency of agitated behaviors in elderly persons, such as hitting, cursing, and restlessness. It consisted of 29 items all rated on a 1 to 7 scale with 1 being the "best" rating and 7 being the "worst" rating. The minimum possible CMAI total score was 29, and the maximum possible CMAI total score was 203. A decrease in score indicated improvement in symptoms.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The full analysis set (FAS) comprised subjects who, after randomization, have received at least 1 dose of the IMP, and from whom CMAI total scores have been obtained at baseline and at least 1 time point after initiation of the treatment.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline and 10 weeks first dose, on average 10 weeks

analyses.groupDescription: Statistical analysis to compare brexpiprazole 2 mg/day and placebo was performed at Week 10.
Statistical analysis to compare brexpiprazole 1 mg/day and placebo was performed at Week 10.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Clinical Global Impression of Severity (CGI-S) Score at 10 Weeks After Dosing.
outcomeMeasures.description: The CGI-S was used to rate the severity of agitation. Scores were: 0 = not assessed; 1 = normal, not at all ill; 2 = borderline mentally ill; 3 = mildly ill; 4 = moderately ill; 5 = markedly ill; 6 = severely ill; and 7 = among the most extremely ill participants. A decrease in score indicated improvement in symptoms.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Efficacy sample（FAS）consisted of all participants who have received at least 1 dose of the IMP and have Baseline and at least one Post-Baseline efficacy evaluation.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline and 10 weeks first dose, on average 10 weeks

outcomeMeasures.title: Clinical Global Impression of Improvement (CGI-I) Score at 10 Weeks After Dosing.
outcomeMeasures.description: The CGI-I Scale was clinician-rated scale which assessed the total improvement of the patient's condition compared to that at baseline. Scores range from 0 to 7: 0 = Not assessed, 1= Very much improved, 2 = Much improved, 3= Minimally improved, 4= No change, 5= Minimally worse, 6= Much worse, 7= Very much worse. Higher scores indicate worse condition.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Efficacy sample（FAS) consisted of all participants who have received at least 1 dose of the IMP and have Baseline and at least one Post-Baseline efficacy evaluation.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline and 10 weeks first dose, on average 10 weeks

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse events were monitored from signing of the informed consent form until follow-up for up to 35 days after the final day of IMP administration, on average 19 weeks
adverseEventsModule.description: The safety analysis comprised subjects who, after randomization, have received at least 1 dose of the IMP.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests brexpiprazole for agitation associated with Alzheimer’s-type dementia — an intervention intended to reduce neuropsychiatric/agitation symptoms (symptom management), not to modify underlying Alzheimer pathology. citeturn0search3turn1search1

Act: Key extracted details — drug name and type: brexpiprazole (also marketed as Rexulti, OPC‑34712), an orally administered small‑molecule atypical antipsychotic/serotonin–dopamine activity modulator; trial doses examined include 1 mg and 2 mg (placebo control used). This matches prior Phase 2/3 and Phase 3 agitation trials of brexpiprazole in Alzheimer’s dementia. citeturn2search0turn0search2turn1search1

Reflect: Classification check — because brexpiprazole is a small‑molecule antipsychotic used to treat behavioral agitation (a neuropsychiatric symptom) rather than targeting amyloid/tau pathology or primarily aiming to enhance cognition, the correct category is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'. This is supported by the JAMA/PMC and FDA trial/approval summaries. citeturn0search3turn1search1

Web search results (key sources consulted): 1) JAMA Neurology / PMC randomized clinical trial reporting brexpiprazole efficacy for agitation in Alzheimer dementia. citeturn0search3 2) PubMed / clinical-trial papers summarizing Phase 2/3 and Phase 3 trials (doses including 1 mg, 2 mg, 3 mg). citeturn0search2turn0search0 3) FDA press announcement approving Rexulti (brexpiprazole) for agitation associated with dementia due to Alzheimer's disease. citeturn1search1 4) Otsuka corporate / product information describing brexpiprazole (mechanism: partial agonist at 5‑HT1A and D2, antagonist at 5‑HT2A; small‑molecule antipsychotic). citeturn2search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests brexpiprazole (Rexulti; OPC‑34712), an orally administered atypical antipsychotic/serotonin–dopamine activity modulator that acts as a partial agonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5‑HT1A receptors and as an antagonist at 5‑HT2A (i.e., it directly modulates neurotransmitter receptors). citeturn1search1turn1search6

Act: Key extracted details — drug name and mechanism: brexpiprazole (Rexulti) targets monoaminergic neurotransmitter receptors (D2, 5‑HT1A, 5‑HT2A and others) and is being used in these trials to treat agitation (a neuropsychiatric/symptom management indication) rather than to modify core AD pathologies such as amyloid or tau. The FDA approved Rexulti for agitation associated with dementia due to Alzheimer’s disease based on two positive 12‑week randomized trials. citeturn1search8turn0search0turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — according to the CADRO taxonomy, interventions that act primarily on neurotransmitter receptors belong to D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. Although the trial is focused on symptom improvement (agitation), the biological target is receptor modulation (serotonin/dopamine), so the most specific and correct CADRO category is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. No evidence in the description indicates disease‑modifying targets (amyloid, tau, inflammation, etc.) or multiple unrelated mechanisms requiring 'R) Multi‑target'. citeturn1search1turn0search3

Web search results (key sources consulted): 1) FDA press release — supplemental approval of Rexulti for agitation associated with dementia due to Alzheimer’s disease (May 11, 2023). citeturn0search0 2) JAMA Neurology / PubMed randomized clinical trial reporting brexpiprazole efficacy for agitation in Alzheimer dementia (Study 213 / NCT03548584). citeturn0search3 3) Lundbeck / Otsuka press releases summarizing Phase 3 results and FDA approval. citeturn0search1turn0search2 4) Preclinical/clinical pharmacology papers describing brexpiprazole as a serotonin–dopamine activity modulator (partial agonist at 5‑HT1A and D2; antagonist at 5‑HT2A). citeturn1search1turn1search2 5) Rexulti clinical pharmacology/prescribing information summarizing pharmacodynamics and receptor profile. citeturn1search6turn1search8
